instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.P5VS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS3_PGOOD? P5VS3_PGOOD indicates that the PP5V_S3 power rail is functioning properly..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message:
hi, i am just have a problem with this board, no fan spin


<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 5.0V
PP3V§_S3 is 3.3V

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> 0V

red on ground i found there(pin 5)  in diode mode 0.091, a good one has there 0.521

i replaced the <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, no fan spin, on pin 5 now is about 0.521, should be ok.

I replaced a second time to be shure but still the same, pin 5 ok but 0V

i removed <RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR> (value is ok) but still <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> pin 5 0V

<RESISTOR>R7247</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7256</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7220</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7221</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7261</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7216</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7246</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7206</RESISTOR>,  values ok

VREG 5, VREG 3 is good


need some help please

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: What is the voltage from pin 1 and pin 2 to ground on <RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message:
5V and 3V were present....why did you touch <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>?????

<SIGNAL>P5VS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is connected to many other power good signals. So another rail is missing and pulling it down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7965</RESISTOR> pin 1 has 0.06V and pin2 has 0.06V


I touched <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> because pin5 measured to ground in diode mode was only 0.091 and compared with a good one should be 0.521
after replacing pin 5 had 0.521 as well

5V and 3V are still present. I found out that <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL> and 3.<SIGNAL>3V_S0</SIGNAL> are present but still no fan spin




<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>  3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5.0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>  3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>  1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL>  1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>  1.5V

<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>   0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0</SIGNAL>   1.22V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>   1.07V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>    1.06V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL>  3.19V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_GPUIFPX</SIGNAL> 1.81V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>  1.81V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_GPU_REG</SIGNAL>  1.51V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>  1.51V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0GPU</SIGNAL>   1.02V
<SIGNAL>PP1V0_S0GPU_ISNS</SIGNAL>   1.02V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>    1.13V

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>   0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>   0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>    1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL>  1.07V

<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG</SIGNAL>  0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message:
No Title

i checked <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG</SIGNAL> and it has (diode mode) it has only 0.007, a good board has about 0.030

looked around and found that

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: i replaced it now and got my fan spin ! yeha :-)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message:
thanks duke and josipaq for help

yes, pin 5 <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> has now 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: so wht is <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_REG</SIGNAL>  for? of course cpu power. but is it for the core? is it the first power on cpu?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: CPU will be dead probably. You could replace the damaged FET and also replace the controller chip! Maybe you get lucky.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: i replaced the cap and got fan spin and a working machine. is it nevertheless necessary to replaye the fet and the controller chip ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dont start, green/orange light is there
threads.message: If the system passes a full ASD test and works without issues there is no reason to replace this
